Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Number Theory at Emory University
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Emory Department of Mathematics and Computer Science REU is a research experience for undergraduates interested in arithmetic geometry, combinatorics, and number theory. Organized by Ken Ono (with assistance from rotating colleagues), the program plans to train ten undergraduates annually in the summers of 2013, 2014, and 2015. Research problems will be accessible and cutting edge, and they will be related to analytic number theory, elliptic curves, Galois representations, modular forms, partitions, and quantum modular forms.

The participants will be chosen from a nationwide search. At least half will be chosen from underrepresented groups, and at least half will be chosen from institutions which do not offer many similar STEM research activities for undergraduates. The REU program will enable undergraduate students to enjoy an enhanced learning experience, including research projects and seminars. The overall goal of the Emory REU in Number Theory is to attract talented undergraduate students to careers in the mathematical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Emory REU in Arithmetic Geometry and Number Theory trained 10 undergraduate students who published 11 papers. The research papers include new results on open problems on elliptic curves, integer partitions, modular forms of various types, distribution of prime numbers, and canonical models of divisors over the field of rational numbers.

The program included lectures by the PI and his fellow instructors, an active research period, training and guidance with respect to the writing of papers for publication and the preparation of lectures at professional meetings. The program concluded with a research symposium where the students presented their findings to an audience of professional mathematicians.

Intellectual Merits: The student participants wrote 11 papers in arithmetic geometry and number theory which solved several open problems.A complete classification of shifted partition identities was obtained. Linnik's Theorem was generalized to the setting of Sato-Tate distributions for elliptic curves. Rose's Conjecture on quasimodular forms was obtained. Robust structure was obtained for rational Q-divisors. A complete classification of q-structures for Rogers-Ramanujan type identities was obtained.

Broader Impacts: The students have given lectures at various undergraduate research conferences such as the Joint Math Meetings in Seattle. The postdoctoral and graduate counselors obtained valuable experience in innovative educational activities. Overall, professional educational and developmental opportunities were offered to 15 young mathematical scientists.
